Summary of RDFa 1.1: A ridiculously verbose way of expressing identical metadata relationships as Microdata.  With datatypes.
TabAtkins: that's not really fair, rdfa does way more than microdata. For example it does per-field typing, and supports XML literals.
I said per-field typing.  ^_^  XML literals is indeed something it has over Microdata.
and it has full CURIE support
That's not a benefit.
oh
well i'm sure it can be sold as a benefit
does microdata do CURIES? I think not!
clearly microdata is inferior
Microdata does CURIES via an implicit @vocab mechanism.
i have no idea what that means but it sounds good, i like it
@vocab is just RDFa1.1's way of making you not need to use prefixes.  Any property nested in the @vocab element that doesn't have a prefix uses the @vocab value as its prefix.
Alternately: the mechanism isn't implicit, but it's covered by @itemtype.
Which I think is actually more accurate.

The RDFa 1.1 spec doesn't do a great job of explaining what all the attributes do.  It took some hunting to discover that @typeof and @datatype are the same thing, with the former for the triple-subject and the latter for the triple-object.
Also: chaining is a bad, confusing idea and I hate it.
Additionally: very confused about why/how @src is always a subject, never an object, but @href is always an object, never a subject.
That's not true.  @src can be an object too, at the same time as it's functioning as a subject and a scoping indicator.

is wondering what to do about positioning captions
considering just the horizontal dimension for now
there are three variables for a cue:
horizontal position, size of the box, and the alignment of the text within the box
http://docs.google.com/drawings/edit?id=1LXroDh1tSee1YM79toEMo6OEdlI2Du5EfoWt7mSmc8U&hl=en
there's two ways i can think of doing this: either aligning the alignment edge to the given horizontal position, or

aligning the point along the box in the horizontal dimension that is the given distance along the box as a fraction of the box width to the equivalent position on the video as a fraction of the video width
the latter works really well if the width is known ahead of time and is not 100%
the former works really well if the horizontal position is less than 75% or so
the latter makes the position irrelevant if the width is 100% though
is just going through email and reached the public-html thread ;)
I'm confused about how the last box in the second example works.
and the former fails dramatically for the case of the position being 100%
Omitted size implies 100%, and thus ignores H?
TabAtkins: the point 50% along the way of the box is aligned to the point 50% along the video
Oh, duh, got it.
TabAtkins: it's just that since the dimension is 100% (presumably, by default), that is indistinguishable to any other position
I like that usage.  It's very natural in CSS backgrounds.
yeah but it totally makes the position useless if the width is not known
it's as bad as the last case in the first box
Unless you introduce some concept of "shrinkwrap" for width.
for the positioning and styling stuff, can't we use CSS directly?
TabAtkins: if we do that, then each cue would align differently
nessy: CSS doesn't have the magic avoidance we need to add for titles to avoid the overlapping titles issue
Yes?  So either you do a definite size, or just deal with it.
TabAtkins: i'd rather the default was pretty :-)
hmmm…
I don't really have an opinion on whether it's better to shrinkwrap or just expand to full width.
The latter seems like it would be fine, personally.
maybe the default should be to do absolute positions, except if you set a width, then it does the second case...
though then you still have the other problem...
i guess the question is
what should happen if you say a left-aligned box is at position 100% horizontally?
does that even make sense?
That's why always doing the latter is best.
So that situation actually produces something good - a right-aligned box.
always doing the latter works fine except when width is automatic, then it's counterintuitive or ugly depending on how we do it
no, it produces a left-aligned box that is the full width of the screen :-)
If the width is auto positioning it doesn't make sense, given our requirement that it shouldn't go out of the screen.
At least, horiz positioning it doesn't.
if the size of the box is 100%, and we use the case-2 alignment mechanism, then the position has no effect
Yes.
yeah maybe that's the answer... if it has no width, then ignore the horizontal positioning
Hixie, overlapping title avoidance ? couldn't you just create pseudo-boxes that become more if there are more subtitles ? styling like video::subtitle:first-of-type() etc ?
(and say so explictly)
Phew.  Just got through Chapter 8 of RDFa 1.1.  There aren't words to describe how stupid the complexity of the processing here is.

I am confused about this whole positioning thing
Unfortuantely there's no way to "fix" it without just dropping the whole concept and saying "Use raw RDF, or Microdata."
words fail me to describe the awesome that animu has in defining this part of the spec

Hixie: do I understand correctly that you are trying to put the avoidance straight into the caption file format?
nessy: straight into the processing model for the format, yeah
not into the format itself
i.e. there should be no syntax for this
it should just happen

if all the tracks are using the same format, then no, you just do it on the fly
for rendering, doesn't matter which track the files come from

the UA
when rendering
(or the media subsystem, or whatever is responsible for this)
ok, follow

ideally, you want a caption format that would be reasonable for either a web engine or a media engine to render

since implementation strategies may differ
othermaciej: yeah, 100% agree
ok, I follow :)
so, why would CSS styling then not work per caption file?
not sure what you mean
why would CSS styling not work?
work for what?
and positioning, I mean
i don't understand how you'd use CSS to do the positioning.
the part of CSS that does positioning
CSS has alignment properties and stuff, right?
I'm trying to understand why there is a need for the horizontal positioning (H) and alignment (A) stuff to be different from CSS
CSS has like a dozen different layout mechanisms, i don't see how any of them would work here though
Actually... Flexbox + abspos would probably work great.
i mean, i intend to define things in term of the block/inline/vertical layout mechanisms, but you still have to position those somehow
TabAtkins: including for http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xG9KluukpJI#t=2m40 ?
ok, just go ahead - maybe things get clearer when I see it all specified
I'm just struggling to follow the logic
Hixie: That'd be absposing the translations of the writing on the picture.
TabAtkins: no i mean the way the second title doesn't move when the first goes away
TabAtkins: and the way the second one appears above the first automatically (without being given explicit instructions of where to appear)
nessy: i might be missing something obvious... if you have a proposal for how to make it work with CSS, i'm all ears
The former - no, unless you have a mechanism for setting things to visibility:hidden when they overlap, then visibility:collapse when they stop overlapping.
I'll see if I can work it out with CSS - maybe then I can see what the issue is :)
The latter, yes.
TabAtkins: i'd like a system where you can position things all over the place then have another title in "defualt" position and have that one just slide to the first "line" where it fits
(In current draft, have a flexbox with box-orient:vertical and box-direction:alternate.  In my current rewritten syntax, just have display:flex-up on the caption container.
TabAtkins: i think either way you end up having to have dedicated code
just one more question: with the S parameter (size) are you trying to do automatic line breaks?
nessy: possibly. The main reason was to have a way to say where the edge was for purposes of avoiding overlaps.
nessy: is there a need for automatic wrapping?

Hixie: In the case that you have something manually positioned in the middle of the screen, and then overlapping text fills the entire bottom fo the screen to just below the positioned text, would a third overlapping segment then go above the manually positioned text?
I don't think so - though I wonder what happens when you change video size, e.g. to to full-screen
TabAtkins: i'd hope so, don't see where else we'd want it to go
if you don't blow up the captions at the same ratio, they look really tiny
nessy: i assume captions will be sized relative to the video
nessy: but i'm more worried about different fonts having different needs for where to wrap
Hixie: In that case we do need a new layout mode.
so, rather than having a S parameter size given in the spec, I would say that S should be calculated by the rendering engine, right?
TabAtkins: right, that's what i'm doing :-)
Something with a notion of intruding abspos, and stability of positioning.
nessy: how do you mean?
are the three parameters in your image H, S, A specified in the caption file or just something that your layout mode deals with?
maybe this is where my whole confusion comes from!
I would think H, A are in the caption file, but S is only in the layout mode
that's one of the things i want to try to work out. I think it's possible that we'd have all three in the track file (though all three optional for each cue of course)
but maybe we can get away with fewer
Extended SRT has H and S
(though expressed as X1 and X2)
if we want to be able to set a background colour whose edge doesn't move around with each cue, we'd need an S
only in the layout mode though, I think
I wonder if just doing a left and right would be better instead.
so e.g. the question is, in the video from which http://junkyard.damowmow.com/425 comes, is the box the same size in each cue?
as an author, I wouldn't really want to have to calculate for every text cue how long it is
if yes, we need an explicit S
Benefit is that it shares well with the "abspos" positioning scheme.
TabAtkins: H+S and X1+X2 are equivalent
Hixie: Yes, but one or the other may be more natural to use.
TabAtkins: how it is written in the file is a separate issue :-)
i'm just trying to work out the processing model for now
it's either a box defined for all text cues in size or it is dynamically adjusted around the size of the current text cue
I think specifying it separately per text cue is a nightmare
to authore
yes i'd expect most authors to let it be implied
i'd expect most authors to not set any of this
that X1 X2 Y1 Y2 of extended SRT is not implemented anywhere is a good sign that it's not useful per text cue
it's only really relevant for cases like http://philip.html5.org/misc/eva-captions.jpg
or http://img3.imageshack.us/img3/6743/vlcsnap090208083027134xq5.png

to me as an author I would think there is top, right, bottom, left, center placement of caption cue box; then there is left, right, center, justify alignment on the text around the center of the caption cue box
it's more complicated than that because of having to deal with which direction the box grows in when it's multiple lines long

then I might define a background formatting for the caption cue box for all captions and either make that adjust to the size of the caption or give it a fixed size into which all my caption cues will fit
the direction in which the box grows is dependent on the charset (is it charset that I use, e.g. for Chinese characters?) and the way in which that charset works - e.g. top-to-bottom or left-to-right
I would think

i don't mean the block-progression-direction, i mean where the box is anchored. Consider http://philip.html5.org/misc/eva-captions.jpg -- if the top caption were one line long, it would be at the top, but if the bottom caption were one line long, it would be at the bottom.
they grow in different directions
http://dashiva.net/misc/1271498287684.jpg shows that oo
too
except there i'd expect the bottom one to grow down, or maybe even be centered, rather than grow up
you wouldn't want the author to have to worry about this for each cue, so you really want good defaults so that just throwing the caption to the top or the bottom gets the right effect
without having to give a dozen coordinates and alignment instructions for each cue
I think we want the same thing
I might just not express it very well
on http://dashiva.net/misc/1271498287684.jpg I would think there are two boxes
a second line in both boxes would always be rendered underneath the first line, but the box center position would move down on the top box and up on the bottom box
yeah
and the author would only say that for the first box it is top position and left aligned, and on the second box that it is bottom positioned and center aligned
ideally though the author would only have to give two instructions, maybe three: for the top box: align left, position at the top; for the bottom box: position at the bottom
or maybe not even anything for the bottom box

Hixie: I've been thinking about some websockets stuff, and have a bit of an idea.. wanted to run it past you if you had a moment?
sure
okay, currently with websockets, they are a two way channel, however, what happens in the case where a websocket server is only interested in streaming data down to a client?
would it make sense to add an extra (optional) headers which allowed you to specific (from the server) whether the connection was to be a ReadOnly connection?
(alternatively, you may also wish to implement a writeOnly, but I can't see a use case for that)

you define the protocol that runs over websocket, so you could just define your protocol such that there is nothing the client is allowed to say, and the server can just ignore everything the client sends
by default, websockets would assume that they are both Read and Write, unless this is set
true, although, would it not be a good idea to give the client some indication of this?
I'm thinking in a more generic sense, rather then at the subprotocol level
this flag would have no effect on the readyState of the connection.
well it's not like the client is a random client, the client is you
i mean, you're not going to be talking to random pages, you're only talking to people who know what your protocol is
so they know your protocol is "read only", because that's why they're connecting to you
not so
the client may be a random client, in the case of a websocket server as an API server
then you're going to have to tell the client a heck of a lot more than just that the server doesn't want anything
you're going to have to tell the client the entire protocol
hmm.. okay, fair enough
it was just a quick idea I had

aboodman: yes
abarth: hey, i was wondering something about cors
doesn't it have the issue where it might leak access to intranet resources?
aboodman: no (unless intranet resources are in the habit of adding Access-Control-Allow-Origin headers randomly)
aboodman: that's one of the threats CORS tries to address
aboodman: do you have something speific you're worried about?
aboodman: in theory it *can* violate integrity (as opposed to confidentiality) of intranet resources, but only in the same ways forms already can
right cors, requires that existing servers respond with a special header.
even for GET.
yes
sorry, forgot that bit.
ooc, if the intranet issue didn't exist, would servers still need to respond with the special header?
depends what you mean by intranet
that is, would not sending credentials be sufficient.
there's always IP-based authentication
for requests without credentials, maybe not
you can't avoid sending credentials
for example, proxy-auth credentials
or IP addresses
"intranet" is a shorthand for a broad category
what about the loopback interface?
does that count as an intranet?
it basically means any resource you have access to by virtue of network position
othermaciej: ok, that shorthand is fine.
abarth: the loopback interface is not behind a firewall, is it?
intranet => any resource you have access to by virtue of network position
it might or might not be.  there are lots of services that bind only to 127.0.0.1
abarth: well, I guess for most home users it is since they are behind a NAT firewall
those aren't "firewalled" per-se
but they're only accessible from the box itself
aboodman: many home routers are reconfigurable via http from the local network segment
aboodman: in many cases this is encoded in firmware that can't readily be upgraded
i guess i'm asking: are there other forms of ambient authority that the browser does not control, other than client IP address.
so "if the intranet issue didn't exist" is a rather huge counter-factual
yeah, it was "out of curiosity"
not related to current debate
the IP address and the routes
for example, I have access to systems on net 17 right now
but my IP address is not on net 17
because I have a VPN tunnel
random attackers cannot send packets to machines behind Apple's firewall even if they can send packets to me

Fragmentation is often the easiest option, although rarely the best.
See also microdata vs. RDFa.  If we knew in advance that only one could exist, whichever one we had would probably be better than either of the two contenders now.
But instead, everyone who likes one of them just ignores the other rather than trying to fix its deficiencies.
To be fair, RDFa seems to be absorbing some of the good ideas of microdata. It just doesn't seem as willing to part with the bad ideas.

AryehGregor: Fwiw, I've done a relatively thorough and open review of RDFa 1.1.  I think it's unfixable at this point, though.  They just made some initial architectural mistakes and have dug themselves down far enough in an attempt to reduce their impact that you can't "fix" it without substantially rewriting it.
The basic failure is not paying enough attention to the tree-based structure of XML, and relying on a notion of implicit subjects, rather than declaring subjects more explicitly.
Then they made it worse by trying to be clever with the chaining concept.
